text: Hi all. Have done some searching but nothing stands out to me. (At the risk of overfitting ) I have a bot running but would like to exclude Trot and Pace races (my father in law has some experience as a bookie on harness races so there is good reason here) Is there a simple way to do this via Flumine/BFLW? thanks in advance

text:
If you have any order which has been placed on the exchange and is Executable but has a VIOLATION status - how do you cancel it from the exchange? I keep getting this error:
raise OrderUpdateError("Current status: %s" % self.status)
flumine.exceptions.OrderUpdateError: Current status: OrderStatus.VIOLATION

text: <@U029XDZ22KB> has joined the channel

Unlike 'Flat' etc. Pace & Trot don't exist as Race Types, so you have to filter them out by checking the market name, something like this:

```for m in market_catalogues:
        if 'AU' in country_codes and 'WIN' in market_types:
            if 'Trot'not in m.market_name and 'Pace' not in m.market_name```

text: I think the message on the raise could be a little clearer, maybe raise OrderUpdateError(f"Incorrect order status : {self.status}. Only orders with status: {OrderStatus.EXECUTABLE} can be cancelled")

elements.text: I think the message on the raise could be a little clearer, maybe raise OrderUpdateError(f"Incorrect order status : {self.status}. Only orders with status: {OrderStatus.EXECUTABLE} can be cancelled")

text: Example here <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/master/examples/exampletwo.py|https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/master/examples/exampletwo.py>

attachments.text:
```
import betfairlightweight
from betfairlightweight import filters


# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient("username", "password", app_key="appKey")

# login
trading.login()

# update for test
market_id = "1.131347484"
selection_id = 12029579


def place_order():
    # placing an order
    limit_order = filters.limit_order(size=2.00, price=1.01, persistence_type="LAPSE")
    instruction = filters.place_instruction(
        order_type="LIMIT",
        selection_id=selection_id,
        side="LAY",
        limit_order=limit_order,
    )
    place_orders = trading.betting.place_orders(
        market_id=market_id, instructions=[instruction]  # list
    )

    print(place_orders.status)
    for order in place_orders.place_instruction_reports:
        print(
            "Status: %s, BetId: %s, Average Price Matched: %s "
            % (order.status, order.bet_id, order.average_price_matched)
        )


def update_order(bet_id):
    # updating an order
    instruction = filters.update_instruction(
        bet_id=bet_id, new_persistence_type="PERSIST"
    )
    update_order = trading.betting.update_orders(
        market_id=market_id, instructions=[instruction]
    )

    print(update_order.status)
    for order in update_order.update_instruction_reports:
        print("Status: %s" % order.status)


def replace_order(bet_id):
    # replacing an order
    instruction = filters.replace_instruction(bet_id=bet_id, new_price=1.10)
    replace_order = trading.betting.replace_orders(
        market_id=market_id, instructions=[instruction]
    )

    print(replace_order.status)
    for order in replace_order.replace_instruction_reports:
        place_report = order.place_instruction_reports
        cancel_report = order.cancel_instruction_reports
        print(
            "Status: %s, New BetId: %s, Average Price Matched: %s "
            % (order.status, place_report.bet_id, place_report.average_price_matched)
        )


def cancel_order(bet_id):
    # cancelling an order
    instruction = filters.cancel_instruction(bet_id=bet_id, size_reduction=2.00)
    cancel_order = trading.betting.cancel_orders(
        market_id=market_id, instructions=[instruction]
    )

    print(cancel_order.status)
    for cancel in cancel_order.cancel_instruction_reports:
        print(
            "Status: %s, Size Cancelled: %s, Cancelled Date: %s"
            % (cancel.status, cancel.size_cancelled, cancel.cancelled_date)
        )

```

text: incoming newbie question..Took a while, but my first full day of running Flumine on an account :grinning: (small profit too). If I wanted to run the same strategy (slightly different triggers) on a second account , would I simply copy the program; give it a different file name and then run that separately? (the way I ran the file was : I just pointed to the relative file path and pasted it in file manager and it opened a terminal C:\windows\Py.exe. Im not sure if this is the correct way to do it (Seemed to work OK)? Sorry for the very basic question. Thanks in advance

text: :scream_cat:
Yep no problem with that, ideally you would pass the username as an argument into the script (sys.argv) so that you are keeping things dry, no point in copying a file just to change a single var

text: <@U02AC3372JC> has joined the channel

What constitutes a live order in flumine - is it an order that has a unmatched amount on a market yet to resolve? As i want to place a follow up bet each time the previous one is matched in the order back, lay , back, lay, back.... so on i was wondering will i have to adjust the max_live_trade_count to something very high in order to do this?

And are orders retrieved in the process_orders function listed in a p[articular way consistently eg placed time descending? Additionally if there is some consistent ordering does this also apply to selection_orders/strategy_orders orders retrieved via the market.blotter so i know when iterating? Thanks for any help everyone :grin:

And are orders retrieved in the process_orders function listed in a p[articular way consistently eg placed time descending? text: <@U0154JA98TH> live orders are orders with an unmatched part, so in your case max_live_trade_count could be set to 1. The total number of orders can be limited by max_trade_count.

elements.text: live orders are orders with an unmatched part, so in your case max_live_trade_count could be set to 1. The total number of orders can be limited by max_trade_count.

text: I would guess they are listed by in order you placed them? I dont know though. How are you planning on using that?

text: trying to work out best way to cycle through the bets placed on a given market. For instance if my strat is working as desired each back bet should have a lay counter part. That means ill only ever need to take into account the last two bets placed as those that came before should have matched and reduced exposure on the runner. So back then lay, once the lay bet is fully matched forget about these two and repeat cycle

elements.text: trying to work out best way to cycle through the bets placed on a given market. For instance if my strat is working as desired each back bet should have a lay counter part. That means ill only ever need to take into account the last two bets placed as those that came before should have matched and reduced exposure on the runner. So back then lay, once the lay bet is fully matched forget about these two and repeat cycle

text: maybe this could work, but it sounds like a very unstable/risky approach. Also, you dont necesarrily need to place a lay bet after a back bet, for example if you placed 1 lay bet, then 1 back bet, then you could just as well place another back bet (making it 2 backs and 1 lay instead of 2 lays, 1 back). I would just cycle through the orders and count back/lay bets. If one is higher than the other, the next bet should be the less placed one and if they r equal, you can place either side next.

elements.text: maybe this could work, but it sounds like a very unstable/risky approach. I would just cycle through the orders and count back/lay bets. If one is higher than the other, the next bet should be the less placed one and if they r equal, you can place either side next.

text: This sounds like a scalping strategy, which would be low risk, but relies on the pairing of back and lay bets to keep it that way. Placing the back bet first keeps the risk down as the liability is smaller on anything with odds > evens.

elements.text: This sounds like a scalping strategy, which would be low risk, but relies on the pairing of back and lay bets to keep it that way. Placing the back bet first keeps the risk down as the liability is smaller on anything with odds > evens.

text: also, given a bet may only be matched partially, its maybe better to add up the matched up parts aswell and then only place more bets once the matched sum >= the full bet size (matched + unmatched) sum of the other side

elements.text: also, given a bet may only be matched partially, its maybe better to add up the matched up parts aswell and then only place more bets once the matched sum >= the full bet size (matched + unmatched) sum of the other side
